EQUITY INVESTMENT AND LOAN SUMMARY 
Investee Company  Tongfang (Harbin) Water Engineering Co., Ltd. (TVVE), a limited 
and Borrower  liability company incorporated under the laws of the People's 
Republic of China (PRC), and based in Harbin, Heilongjiang province. 
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector (subsector): Water supply and other municipal infrastructure 
and services (water supply and sanitation) 
Themes (subthemes):  Economic growth  (promoting economic 
efficiency and enabling business environment), private sector 
development (private sector investment), environmental sustainability 
(urban environmental improvement) 
Environmental and  Environment: B 
Social Safeguards  Involuntary resettlement: B 
Classification  Indigenous peoples: C 
Project Description  The project will support TVVE's expansion and capital expenditure 
plan to build, rehabilitate, expand, upgrade, privatize, and/or operate 
water supply and wastewater treatment subprojects in the Songhua 
River Basin in the PRC. TVVE will use the proceeds from the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) financing to finance its portfolio of water 
supply and wastewater treatment subprojects in the Songhua River 
Basin. 
Proposed ADB  The proposed equity investment will be the lesser of $10 million or 
Assistance  15% of the paid-up equity capital in TVVE. 
The proposed loan facility to TVVE will comprise an A loan of up to 
CNY250 million, funded by ADB, and a B loan of up to $100 million, 
funded under a participation agreement by commercial banks in 
dollars. 
Impact, Outcome,  The project will be an important catalyst for economic growth and 
and Benefits  environmental improvement in the PRC, particularly in the 
underdeveloped Songhua River Basin. Specifically, the project will (i) 
expedite the delivery of urban water supply, sanitation, and 
wastewater services in the PRC, and thereby accelerate the 
achievement of Millennium Development Goal target 10; (ii) increase 
provision of reliable sources of clean water in scarce water resource 
areas, arrest increasing pollution of water resources, and reduce 
threats to public health generally; (iii) promote private sector 
participation in urban water supply, sanitation, and wastewater 
management in the PRC, and thereby increase the amount of private 
capital invested in the urban water sector, which is crucial for the 
sustainable and efficient delivery of basic services; and (iv) promote 
public—private partnership in development of urban water supply, 
sanitation, and wastewater management in the PRC.

Project Sponsor  Tsinghua Tongfang Co., Ltd. (TTC), a publicly listed company, with 
Tsinghua University, through Tsinghua Holdings Co., Ltd., as its 
largest single shareholder. 
Justification and  ADB assistance for the project will be justified based on the value 
ADB Value-Added  ADB can add to the project and the projects development impacts 
and demonstration effects. ADB's assistance is merited because the 
project (i) supports the government's 11th Five-Year Plan and 
environmental policies that prioritize the development of water and 
sanitation infrastructure; (ii) is in line with ADB's current country 
partnership strategy; (iii) is consistent with ADB's water policy and 
initiatives; (iv) serves as a demonstration and catalyst, reflecting the 
infrastructure focus of ADB's private sector operations in the PRC; 
and (v) will promote the development of the local capital and financing 
markets.

THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
equity investment in Tongfang (Harbin) Water Engineering Co., Ltd. (TVVE), and (ii) a proposed 
loan to TVVE for the Songhua River Basin Water Pollution Control and Management Project 
Private Sector Facility in the People's Republic of China (PRC). TVVE will use the proceeds of 
the proposed equity investment and loan to finance its portfolio of water supply and wastewater 
treatment subprojects in Heilongjiang province, the PRC. If approved, the project will constitute 
the 27th private sector investment of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in the PRC. 
BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 
A.  Project Identification and Selection 
2.  The project is considered the latest component of the assistance program that ADB has 
been providing to the Songhua River Basin (SRB) with regard to water supply and wastewater 
treatment since the successful ADB technical assistance (TA) project in 2002.1  Most of the 
subprojects that the project will cover are linked to the Songhua River Basin Water Pollution 
Prevention and Control Master Plan (SRBPCMP), to which the TA has provided substantial 
inputs. In 2003, when the TA was implemented, ADB's public sector and private sector 
operations formed an in-house partnership and started to apply joint efforts to address the 
enormous funding requirements in the potential projects being identified. 
3.  ADB started discussions with TVVE in the seminar conducted by ADB (a joint activity of 
the PRC Resident Mission and ADB Private Sector Operations Department [PSOD]) in July 
2007. All TVVE's subprojects have common impacts, which are to improve the urban 
environment and enhance the quality of life in Heilongjiang province, and to contribute 
significantly to pollution control in the SRB. ADB identified TWE as a proper private sector 
vehicle to tackle the water concerns in the SRB and contribute to the implementation of the 
SRBPCMP, in which ADB public sector operations already play a significant role. 
B.  Sector Background 
1.  People's Republic of China Wastewater Sector 
4.  The PRC initiated market-oriented economic reforms in 1978, and since then rapid 
urbanization has accompanied high levels of economic growth. Policies to open the country to 
international trade and investment have made the PRC one of the world's fastest-growing 
economies. Gross domestic product in 2008 was CNY30,067 billion, compared with CNY362.4 
billion in 1978. Per capita gross domestic product in 2008 was CNY24,640. The country has 
reached the Millennium Development Goal (MDG) of cutting the 1990 poverty rate by half, and 
is on track to reach most of the other MDGs. In the process, the PRC's urban population has 
more than tripled, from 190 million in 1980 to 607 million in 2008, accounting for 45.7% of the 
national population, and is expected to reach 47.0% by 2010, 50.0% by 2015, and 55.0% by 
2020. This represents the largest and most rapid rural—urban migration in global history and 
understandably presents numerous challenges to policy makers, urban planners, and those 
responsible for the day-to-day management of urban services. 
1 
ADB. 2002. Technical Assistance to the People's Republic of China for Songhua River Water Quality and Pollution 
Control Management. Manila.

2 
5. Rapid urbanization in the PRC has taken a severe toll on the environment, and has also 
challenged the capacity of local governments to promote good governance, effective planning 
and management, sustainable financing, and timely delivery of public services. While significant 
progress has been made in building urban infrastructure over the past two decades, it tends to 
be concentrated on the more highly developed eastern and southern coastal plains. The 
expansion and upgrading of public services has not kept pace with rapid industrial growth. The 
migration to urban centers currently taking place in the inland regions (in response to 
government policies to promote economic development and job creation in these areas) is 
putting a further strain on urban infrastructure and services. 
6. Cities in the north and west of the PRC and around the SRB are experiencing 
widespread pollution caused by the discharge of untreated wastewater. Shortages of safe 
drinking water are also common, particularly in the north of the PRC. The government has 
classified more than 108 cities as having serious water problems, and 60 as being critically 
short of water. The situation has been exacerbated by the pollution of raw water sources by the 
discharge of inadequately treated agricultural, municipal, and industrial wastewater. 
7. According to latest figures mentioned in the 2008 China Environment Status Report, 2  
65% of the national annual total wastewater generation, equivalent to 57.2 billion tons (t) per 
year, was treated. The annual total chemical oxygen demand discharge was 13.207 million t (a 
decrease of 4.4% from 2007 levels) and that of ammoniacal nitrogen discharge was 1.27 million 
t (a decrease of 4.0% from 2007 levels). These reductions in pollution are results of increased 
efforts mainly in point source pollution interception and treatment. Despite these welcome 
developments, water quality improvement is still slow in most of the country's surface waters 
and groundwater sources that have become polluted to unacceptable levels. In 2008, the 
Ministry of Environment's river water quality monitoring results disclosed that approximately 
45% of the 200 major rivers had a water quality of less than class IV or V. 3  Eutrophication due to 
nutrient pollution has occurred frequently in many of the PRC's lakes. Water quality is 
considered adequate in only 72% of the 222 surface drinking water sources serving 113 major 
cities, and approximately 90% of urban water bodies are polluted. Major pollution sources are 
from urban sewerage as well as nonpoint sources of pollution. The World Bank estimates the 
PRC's annual economic losses due to pollution-related water shortages amount to about 
0NY147 billion. 
2.  Songhua River Basin 
8. The SRB is the third-largest river basin in the PRC, after the Yangtze and Yellow rivers. It 
has an area of 557,000 square kilometers (km2) and a population of 62 million. Agriculture is 
well developed and there is a large industrial base. The Songhua River catchment covers 
portions of three provinces and one autonomous region—Heilongjiang, Jilin, and Liaoning 
provinces, and the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. About 48.4% of the catchment is 
located in Heilongjiang province (covering 59.4% of the provincial territory), 24.1% in Jilin 
province (71.6% of the provincial territory), 27.4% in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region 
(12.9% of the autonomous regions territory), and 0.1% in Liaoning province (0.36% of the 
provincial territory). The Songhua River has two headwaters: in the west, the Nenjiang River, 
which originates from Yilehuli Mountain of the Greater Hinggan mountain range; and in the 
2  Government of the People's Republic of China. Ministry of Environmental Protection. 2008. Annual State of the 
Environment Report. Beijing. 
PRC water quality standards have five classes of quality covering about 40 pollution parameters. Class I is pristine, 
while class V is suitable only for industrial use. Class III is the minimum water quality required for municipal water 
supply.

3 
south, the Second Songhua River, which originates from the Heavenly Lake on top of the 
Changbaishan Mountain. The two rivers converge at Sanchakou (at the border of Heilongjiang 
and Jilin provinces) to form the Songhua River which joins the Heilongjiang River, enters the 
Russian Federation, and eventually discharges to the sea. 
9. The SRB is seriously polluted and is acknowledged by the government to be one of the 
four most polluted river basins in the PRC. Water pollution in the SRB, especially in relation to 
the protection of drinking water resources for the municipality of Harbin, has received increased 
national and international attention following a widely publicized pollution incident in the SRB in 
November—December 2005. The Songhua River is contaminated with a number of known and 
suspected trace organic chemicals, metals, and conventional pollutants. It is classified by the 
government as class IV in some sections of the Songhua River (and even falls into class V 
during the 6-month low-flow winter season), and is considered unsuitable for municipal domestic 
water use. In March 2003, ADB approved the Harbin Water Supply Project ($100 million)4  to 
address the needs of Harbin City, with a population of 3 million, for clean and reliable drinking 
water from an alternative water source (the Lalin River), since the existing source from the 
Songhua River was highly polluted. 
3.  Key Problems and Opportunities 
10. Key problems and opportunities include (i) shortage of good quality drinking water; 
(ii) inadequate wastewater treatment capacity and inefficient operation; and (iii) insufficient 
investment, particularly through private sector participation, in the sector. A key element for 
success in accelerating the achievement of MDG target 10 is the development of bankable 
projects, which are able to leverage government funds and raise the balance of the investment 
capital required from other sources, including commercial and development banks and the 
private sector. 
11. Reducing the pollution of rivers and lakes and improving the supply of clean drinking 
water is part of any pro-poor development strategy. Poor people are most vulnerable to 
environment-induced diseases and are least capable of paying for adequate medical attention 
for digestive tract ailments associated with drinking polluted water. The pollution of rivers and 
lakes reduces already scarce drinking water sources. Bottled water is a very expensive 
alternative to potable tap water. The financial burden of buying bottled water falls most heavily 
on the poor and can account for a disproportionately high proportion of their limited income. 
Much remains to be done to reduce the adverse impacts of water pollution on the poor and to 
end shortages of clean drinking water. 
12. The responsibility for developing water infrastructure falls on local municipalities. 
However, funding for water infrastructure in municipalities in underdeveloped areas, such as the 
SRB, is limited, mainly because (i) they are constrained by limited financial budgets and overall 
infrastructure needs, (ii) they do not have direct access to multilateral or other external financing 
sources, and (iii) some municipalities may not be able to meet the government's counterpart 
funding requirements. Private sector funding is clearly needed for both the water supply and 
wastewater treatment sectors. Private sector participation can also lead to more use of new 
technology and enhance efficiency. 
ADB. 2003.  Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the 
People's Republic of China for the Harbin Water Supply Project.  Manila. The project districts are receiving the new 
high quality of water.

4 
13. In the 11th Five-Year Plan (FYP), the government prioritized environmental issues, 
including water and air pollution, through policy reform, more investment, and better urban 
infrastructure management. Recognizing that adequate environmental protection and pollution 
controls are essential for sustainable economic growth, the government has incorporated 
environmental protection as a national priority in its development strategy. In addition to 
enacting environmental protection laws and implementing regulations that emphasize 
preventive measures, the polluter-pays principle, and decentralized environmental management, 
the government has also undertaken numerous programs, including for wastewater 
management.8  The government has decreed that, by 2010, the wastewater treatment rate in all 
cities of the PRC should not be lower than 60%, and that it should not be lower than 70% for the 
major cities' with secondary treatment facilities. The treatment level required is dependent on 
the water environmental functions or quality class of the receiving water body. To achieve water 
quality class I, II, or III, secondary wastewater treatment would normally be required. 
14. The government's strategy focuses on (i) developing water sources; (ii) protecting 
existing sources by controlling industrial and residential pollution; (iii) introducing water-efficient 
technologies and operations; and (iv) using appropriate pricing mechanisms to encourage 
conservation and generate necessary funds for operation, maintenance, and investment. The 
government's ongoing economic and enterprise reform programs require that all water supply 
and wastewater projects be financially sustainable and capable of cost recovery. 
15. The government is focusing more attention on improving water quality in the SRB during 
the current FYP and the next two FYPs. The PRC top leadership has expressed strong support 
for pollution reduction and water quality improvement in the SRB, and the overall target is to 
ensure that water quality in the SRB meets the PRC class III water quality standard by 2020. 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
1.  Consistency with Strategy 2020 
16. The project is consistent with ADB's Strategy 2020,8  which identified infrastructure and 
environment as two of the five core areas in which ADB will employ its financial and institutional 
resources to maximize results, efficiency, and impact. To contribute to public health, in urban 
infrastructure ADB will focus on water supply, sanitation, and waste management. ADB 
investment in infrastructure is fundamental to achieving poverty reduction and inclusive growth, 
and can also contribute to environmentally sustainable growth and regional integration. Under 
Strategy 2020, ADB's infrastructure operations will emphasize public–private partnerships 
(PPPs) and private sector engagement. ADB will promote a larger role for the private sector in 
financing infrastructure, either as a project sponsor or as an institutional bond or equity investor. 
The equity investor role carries great promise for augmenting the supply of capital for 
developing infrastructure in the region. In another core area—environment—ADB will assist

These include cities directly under the central government, provincial capital cities, and key tourist cities.

developing member countries (DMCs) and their municipalities address a range of environmental 
problems resulting from rapid urbanization. 
2.  Consistency with the Country Strategy 
17.  The project is in line with ADB's country strategy and program in the PRC, 9  which has 
improving the environment as one of its five priority areas of focus. The project reflects the 
infrastructure focus of ADB's private sector operations in the PRC. In the infrastructure sector, 
ADB prioritizes pioneering projects with bankable contractual and financial structuring to 
encourage private sector participation and enhance management expertise. The proposed 
project is a supplementary private sector facility of the Songhua River Basin Water Pollution 
Control and Management Project,1°  which was approved by ADB on 11 December 2008. The 
two ADB projects are trying to create a new, comprehensive PPP model, which is replicable in 
the water sector or other urban infrastructure-related businesses in the PRC and other DMCs. 
3.  Consistency with the Water Policy 
18.  The project is consistent with ADB's Water Policy11  and the Water Financing Program 
2006-2010. 12  In response to the huge unmet water needs in Asia and the Pacific, and 
13 
consistent with the recommendations of various international initiatives   to double water 
investments, ADB has made water a core business area and envisages doubling its water 
investments to more than $2 billion annually.14  
4.  Consistency with Other Relevant ADB Operations 
19. During the processing of the Harbin Water Supply Project, ADB held extensive 
discussions with the government on addressing pollution control in the SRB. Consequently, in 
2002 ADB provided TA for water quality and pollution control management in the SRB. 
20. The TA project, which was highly successful,  15  had the following impacts: First, it 
developed a long-term vision for the SRB, consisting of a strategic plan identifying water quality 
objectives, targets and reforms, and the strengthening of the existing river basin and pollution 
control management practices, and proposed a long-term physical investment program. Second, 
it  strengthened the capacity of key organizations responsible for pollution control and 
management at both the river basin and regional level, and prepared a road map outlining the 
key milestones leading to the development of a river basin management framework within the 
PRC. Third, it identified knowledge gaps relating particularly to nonpoint sources of pollution, 
water quality assessment (notably micropollutants), and water quality inventories. Fourth, it

developed an overall strategic plan for the SRB, both refining and prioritizing existing strategic

strategic plan includes the identification of an investment plan to be implemented over 15 years. 
Fifth, it assisted the government to develop a long-term water pollution control plan for the SRB 
beyond 2010, and provided strategic policy inputs to the 11th FYP and the SRBPCMP. The 
SRBPCMP (2006-2010), approved by the State Council on 29 March 2006, is an action 
program to set pollution control targets for the SRB for 2006-2010, requiring that urban 
environmental pollution and ecological damage be controlled by 2010. Untreated wastewater is 
a major problem in the SRB, and the SRBPCMP specifies that the wastewater treatment rate in 
large and medium-sized cities should not be less than 70% by 2010. The significant increase in 
wastewater treatment capacity under the proposed project would contribute to the target of 
improving the water quality in the SRB from the current class IV and class V to class III by 2020. 
21. The Jilin Water Supply and Sewerage Development Project 16  ($100 million), approved in 
2005, was the first major ADB investment directly addressing pollution control in the SRB. The 
Jilin Urban Environmental Improvement Project 17  ($100 million), approved in 2007, was the 
second, and it follows the priority list of the SRBPCMP. The Songhua River Basin Water 
Pollution Control and Management Project ($200 million) was the third major ADB investment in 
the SRB, and it also follows the priority list of the SRBPCMP. The proposed project will be the 
fourth ADB investment, and the first private sector operation, complementing the previous public 
sector operations in the SRB. This comprehensive strategic approach to addressing pollution 
control in the SRB will serve as a model for demonstration and replication elsewhere in the PRC 
and other DMCs. The proposed project will help the concerned counties and cities in 
Heilongjiang province to achieve a wastewater treatment rate of 70% by 2012. Key areas for 
replication include (i) the approach to studying the complex issues of SRB water quality and 
pollution control management; (ii) the river basin approach to managing water quality; 
(iii) the strategic pollution control action plan, which combines technical assessment, identifying 
investments on a prioritized basis, and institutional planning; (iv) prioritized investments and 
related capacity building; and (v) PPP. 
22. Underdeveloped wastewater collection and wastewater treatment has led to the 
discharge of untreated wastewater into local rivers, and eventually to the pollution of the SRB. 
Water quality in some sections of the Songhua River and its tributaries does not meet class V of 
the PRC surface water quality standard. The lack of adequate wastewater management 
degrades local rivers, poses a threat to public health, and adversely affects the quality of life in 
the SRB. There is an urgent need to expand the sewer network and wastewater treatment 
capacity. In accordance with the SRBPCMP, local governments have identified the prioritized 
projects, to be funded by the public sector or the private sector, or jointly. 
23. The proposed project builds on and furthers ADB policy dialogue with the government in 
several key areas, including (i) cost recovery and tariff reform, (ii) wastewater management, (iii) 
upstream and basinwide pollution prevention and control, (iv) water conservation, (v) corporate 
governance and enterprise reform, and (vi) private sector participation. The cost recovery 
regulations are stipulated in the national guidelines on water supply and wastewater treatment. 
ADB has supported the water tariff reform process through two water tariff TA projects 18  with the

guidelines for wastewater tariffs, and improve urban wastewater management. ADB is also 
supporting the government to develop national policy frameworks for wastewater and solid-
waste tariffs, including tariff calculation methodologies focusing on small cities and towns. 2°  
24.  ADB has also provided TA support to the government on the use of market-based 
instruments to enhance private sector partnership in public utilities, mainly for water supply, and 
wastewater.21  This TA analyzed the issues in the context of international best practices and how 
these could be adopted in the PRC. ADB conducted a seminar (a joint activity of the PRC 
Resident Mission and PSOD) in Beijing on 25 July 2007 on ADB's nonsovereign lending 
operations for the provinces of Heilongjiang and Jilin. 
III.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Project Description 
25.  The project, which provides for an equity investment and loan by ADB, will support the 
expansion and capital expenditure plan of TVVE to build, rehabilitate, expand, upgrade, privatize, 
and/or operate water supply and wastewater treatment facilities in the SRB the PRC. 
1.  The Sponsor and Borrower 
a.  Sponsor 
26.  The project sponsor is Tsinghua Tongfang Co., Ltd. (TTC), a reputable listed company 
headquartered in Beijing. TTC was established by the renowned Tsinghua University in 1997, 
by merging several businesses owned by the school. TTC went public in the same year, and 
listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange. Tsinghua University, through Tsinghua Holdings Co., 
Ltd., is still the largest single shareholder of TTC. 
b.  Borrower 
27.  TVVE was established in May 2004 for the purpose of TTC's first, and still the largest, 
sanitation investment—the Harbin Taipin Wastewater Treatment Plant with a capacity of 
325,000 t/day.

28.  In 2006, TVVE, with strong support from TTC, entered into a memorandum of 
understanding with the Heilongjiang provincial government (HPG) to undertake certain tasks 
defined in the SRBPCMP, after it successfully built and commissioned the Harbin Taipin 
Wastewater Treatment Plant. TTC's funding capacity and TVVE's technical strength, 
construction and operation experience, and investment structuring strategy are well recognized 
by the local governments, and in turn help TVVE to develop the market in Heilongjiang. 
2.  Project Outputs and Outcome 
29.  The project will enhance the urban environment and improve public health and the 
quality of life for urban residents in the project cities and counties in Heilongjiang province. This 
will be achieved by expanding wastewater treatment coverage and improving the supply of 
potable water. The outcome of the project will be reduced pollution and improved water supply 
and wastewater management, through PPP, in the SRB. 
B.  Development Impact 
1.  Contribution to Economic Growth and Poverty Reduction 
30.  One of the key development impacts of the project will be to expedite the delivery of 
urban water supply, sanitation, and wastewater services in the PRC, and thereby accelerate the 
achievement of MDG target 10 in the PRC. The shortage of clean drinking water sources and 
water pollution are threatening public health and the economic growth of the country. 
Investments in wastewater treatment will improve the environment and help arrest pollution of 
water sources, facilitating delivery of water that meets national standards and reducing threats 
to public health. Poor people tend to suffer the most economically from increased medical costs 
or loss of income as a result of waterborne diseases. An increase in the water supply will enable 
increased industrial output, among other benefits. Access to piped water supply increases 
productivity by eliminating time spent in fetching and queuing for water—time which can now be 
channeled to other productive activities. Investments in water and wastewater will reduce these 
costs and contribute to improving the living conditions of the poor and promoting inclusive 
economic growth. 
2.  Private Sector Development 
31.  The project will promote private sector participation in urban water supply, sanitation, 
and wastewater management in the PRC, and thereby increase the amount of private capital 
invested in the urban water sector. This is crucial for the sustainable and efficient delivery of 
basic services as the resources available within government, especially at the local level, are 
limited. The project has a strong demonstration effect on PPP, and will establish a precedent in 
meeting huge funding requirements in environment protection. The project, together with other 
related ADB sovereign operations, provides a good example of how the government and ADB 
can mobilize sufficient resources—from sovereign, quasi-sovereign, multilateral, bilateral, 
domestic private sector, foreign government, and foreign investors—to address a common 
development concern and jointly work on a sustainable solution.

9 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Holding Company 
32. TVVE, after attracting strategic investments from ADB and other investors, will focus on 
developing water supply and wastewater treatment facilities in the SRB. 
33. TVVE will maintain the current business strategies and procedures, with support from 
ADB for environmental and social safeguards management. 
2.  Water Supply and Wastewater Treatment Subprojects 
34. TVVE sets up different project companies, which are all wholly owned, or effectively 
wholly owned, by TWE, to manage various water supply and wastewater treatment subprojects 
in different cities in Heilongjiang province. Each subproject will be one type of PPP with the 
relevant local government, such as build—operate—transfer for one VVVVTP, or privatization of 
existing water supply facility in a particular area. The project developer is selected through 
either public tendering or bilateral negotiation with underlying competitive selection. For any 
greenfield subproject, the feasibility study, environmental impact assessment, and project 
design are prepared by the project developer and approved by local government. Each 
subproject is implemented in accordance with granted approvals, and during construction and 
operation is subject to government inspections on various aspects, including environment, 
safety, quality, and sanitation. 
35. The inflow and outflow volumes are metered with minimum offtake quantities in all the 
subprojects. The qualities of inflow and outflow are monitored on a real-time basis, 24 hours a 
day, by the local environmental protection bureaus through remote testing equipment. The 
bureaus also conduct random inspections on treatment processes. 
3.  Anticorruption and Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of 
Terrorism 
36.  TTC and TWE were advised of ADB's Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) 
and policy relating to the Combating of Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism 
(2003). Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and transparency, 
ADB will require TWE to institute, maintain, and comply with internal procedures and controls 
following international best practice standards for the purpose of preventing corruption or money 
laundering activities or the financing of terrorism, and covenant with ADB to refrain from 
engaging in such activities. Such obligations shall be contained in the loan and equity 
investment documentation, which will further allow ADB to investigate any violation or potential 
violation of these undertakings. 
D.  Unique Features 
37.  Integrated river basin management.  The proposed project is an integral part of the 
basin-wide Songhua water resources management initiative, and the SRBPCMP. It will 
complement ongoing ADB sovereign operations to address pollution control in the SRB. The 
water quality improvements will contribute to integrated water resource management and 
pollution control, a basinwide management program, and transboundary pollution prevention 
and control. The proposed project reflects a continuation of ADB's effort to improve the 
environment of the SRB.

38.  Public—private partnership.  The proposed project is catalyzing additional public and 
private sector investments in reducing pollution in the SRB. ADB's East Asia Department and 
PSOD are adopting a PPP approach to address the significant wastewater treatment funding 
needs for the SRB. The HPG is also strongly promoting PPP in the water supply and 
wastewater treatment sector to solve the funding shortage problem, and improve management 
and operational efficiency. The PPP models being applied in the project include privatization, 
build—operate—transfer, operation concession, etc. Further, the project will source equity funding 
from foreign strategic investors. Due to the competitiveness of private water companies in 
Singapore and the strong potential of their involvement, the Government of Singapore, 
represented by the Public Utilities Board and Singapore Cooperation Enterprise, has committed 
to provide support to the HPG with regards to water resource management and water projects 
development.

11 
IV.  THE PROPOSED ASSISTANCE 
A.  The ADB Assistance 
1.  Equity Investment 
39.  The proposed equity investment will involve the acquisition of ordinary shares in TVVE for 
up to the lesser of 15% of the total paid-up equity capital of TVVE or $10 million, funded from 
ADB's ordinary capital resources. 
2.  Loan 
40. The proposed ADB loan facility will comprise an A loan, to be funded by ADB, and a B 
loan, to be funded by commercial banks under an ADB participation agreement. 
41. The A loan is for up to 0NY250 million, provided from ADB's ordinary capital resources 
without government guarantee, and will be funded from the proceeds of yuan-denominated 
bonds issued by AD B.22  
42. The B loan, for up to $100 million, will be participated in by international commercial 
banks. 
B.  Justification for ADB Assistance 
43.  ADB's assistance for the project is justified based on its development impacts and 
demonstration effects. It will support the government's development plan and ADB's operational 
strategies. ADB's participation in the project will add substantial value in the following ways: 
The project aims to contribute towards meeting MDG target 10 on water and 
sanitation in the PRC. In the PRC, 268 million people need to be provided access 
to safe drinking water, and another 372 million need the provision of sanitation, in 
order to reach MDG target 10 by 2015. 
(ii) The project supports the government's 11th FYP, which has accorded priority to 
the resolution of problems related to water pollution and scarcity of water 
resources. The project will contribute to the achievement of the government's 
targets in urban sewage treatment and water supply capacity. The government 
will continue to promote urbanization to develop and expand markets and to 
create jobs. This will in turn increase the demand for water-related infrastructure. 
(iii) The project will help improve critically needed water infrastructure in the SRB 
where there is a pronounced water resource shortage. Municipalities and 
industries to be covered by the project will benefit from a package of benefits that 
include capital, high-grade technology transfer, and managerial expertise. 
(iv) The project is consistent with ADB's Water Policy (footnote 11) and the Water 
Financing Program 2006-2010 (footnote 12). In response to the huge unmet 
water needs of Asia and the Pacific, and consistent with the recommendations of 
various international initiatives to double water investments (footnote 13), ADB 
has made water a core business area and envisages doubling its water 
investments to more than $2 billion annually (footnote 14). 
22 
The disbursement in yuan will be subject to ADB's funding availability. If ADB is unable to procure sufficient yuan to 
fund the A loan. TVVE can request ADB to disburse all or part of the A loan in dollars.

12 
(v) The project is in line with ADas country strategy and program in the PRC which 
has improving the environment as one of its five priority areas of focus. The 
project reflects the infrastructure focus of ADIB's private sector operations in the 
PRC. In the infrastructure sector. ADB prioritizes pioneering projects with 
bankable contractual and financial structuring to encourage private sector 
participation and enhance management expertise. 
(vi) The project also aims to catalyze both public sector and private sector 
investments in pollution control management in the SRB. The PPP approach 
taken by ADB's East Asia Department and PSOD has a strong demonstration 
effect for any future large infrastructure investment program requiring significant 
capital. The approach should replicable in other sectors, provinces, or DMCs. 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
44.  I am satisfied that the proposed equity investment and loan would comply with the 
Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board 
approve 
(i) an equity investment of up to $10,000,000 in Tongfang (Harbin) Water 
Engineering Co., Ltd. from ADB's ordinary capital resources: and 
(ii) an A loan of up to CNY250,000,000 to Tongfang (Harbin) Water Engineering Co., 
Ltd. from ADB's ordinary capital resources without government guarantee: and a 
B loan in an amount of up to $100,000,000 to be funded by international 
commercial banks, 
for the Songhua River Basin Water Pollution Control and Management Project Private Sector 
Facility, and on such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those 
set forth in this report and as may be reported to the Board.
